questions.text:
The response options for the next 2 items are the same. Select one answer for each item in the set.
For each patient with nausea and vomiting, select the most likely causal organism.
A 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting for the past 1 hour. The patient has not had diarrhea or fever. Two hours ago, he ate a sandwich and coleslaw from a deli. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He works as a computer scientist. He appears ill. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 122/68 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Abdominal examination shows diffuse mild tenderness with no rigidity, rebound, or guarding.
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Campylobacter jejuni is the most common cause of bacterial diarrhea in the US. It commonly affects children and may lead to bloody diarrhea. This bacterium is typically transmitted by the ingestion of contaminated food or via direct contact with infected animals (e.g., puppies). However, the incubation period is a couple of days and the patient does not report having diarrhea, making infection with C. jejuni unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Bacillus cereus can produce two different enterotoxins which cause two distinct food poisoning syndromes. The emetic form, caused by cereulide, leads to nausea and vomiting approximately 1–3 hours after ingestion, similar to this patient's presentation. However, this form is associated with the ingestion of heated food that was improperly refrigerated, most typically rice. The diarrheal form of B. cereus infection can be caused by a broad range of improperly refrigerated food that is not heated before consumption, e.g., vegetables and meat on a sandwich, but manifests with diarrhea 8–16 hours after ingestion.

C) INCORRECT:

Yersinia enterocolitica causes inflammatory diarrhea (may be bloody in severe cases), typically after ingesting contaminated milk or pork. This pathogen may also cause vomiting and abdominal tenderness in the right lower quadrant, which may mimic appendicitis (known as pseudoappendicitis). The incubation period is a couple of days. This patient developed nausea and vomiting 1 hour following the ingestion of contaminated food. Therefore, an infection with Y. enterocolitica is unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli (EHEC) produces verotoxin/Shiga-like toxin that causes bloody diarrhea (known as “enterohemorrhagic colitis”) and potentially nausea and vomiting. It can affect healthy adults (typically leading to an asymptomatic infection), but mainly affects newborns and older individuals. Transmission also occurs via the ingestion of contaminated food (e.g., raw beef and vegetables, milk), but the incubation period is longer (2–10 days). If toxins become systemic, hemolytic uremic syndrome may result.

E) CORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus (a gram-positive bacterium) is a common cause of food poisoning. Ingestion of preformed toxins (produced by S. aureus) in contaminated food (e.g., eggs, dairy products, mayonnaise) typically causes a rapid onset of illness (1–6 hours after ingestion) with nausea and vomiting. Resolution of symptoms normally occurs within 24–48 hours and antibiotics are not indicated.

F) INCORRECT:

Entamoeba histolytica can cause intestinal amebiasis, which is characterized by loose stools containing mucus and bright red blood, painful defecation, abdominal pain, cramps, anorexia/weight loss, and fever. Amebiasis has an incubation period of 1–4 weeks. This patient does not have diarrhea and the incubation period of his infection was approximately 1 hour, making amebiasis unlikely.

G) INCORRECT:

The hallmarks of an infection with Salmonella enteritidis are high-grade fever, severe vomiting, and inflammatory (watery-bloody) diarrhea. Salmonella is typically transmitted via the ingestion of contaminated food (poultry, poorly pasteurized eggs, and milk). The incubation period is 6–48 hours and is largely dependent on the bacterial load in the contaminated food.

H) INCORRECT:

Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC) produces heat-labile as well as heat-stable enterotoxins, which cause diffuse watery diarrhea associated with abdominal cramping, nausea, and possibly vomiting. ETEC has an incubation period of 9 hours to 3 days and is the most common cause of traveler's diarrhea. This patient does not have a recent travel history and the incubation of his infection was approximately 1 hour. Therefore, ETEC infection is unlikely.

I) INCORRECT:

Shigella dysenteriae enters the gastrointestinal tract, leading to inflammation, mucosal damage, and bloody diarrhea. It has an incubation period of 1–3 days. This patient does not have bloody diarrhea and he developed the symptoms only 1 hour following food ingestion. These findings suggest a different organism.

J) INCORRECT:

Vibrio parahaemolyticus can cause foodborne illness, but this typically occurs 16–72 hours after the ingestion of undercooked seafood. This bacterium is the most common cause of diarrhea in Japan. This patient has not had seafood and the incubation of his infection was approximately 1 hour. Therefore, infection with V. parahaemolyticus is unlikely.
questions.hint: The rapid onset of vomiting (following the ingestion of coleslaw; presumably containing mayonnaise) is a typical feature seen in patients infected with this underlying organism.

questions.text:
For each patient with nausea and vomiting, select the most likely causal organism.
A 32-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of nausea and vomiting for the past 2 hours. The patient has not had diarrhea or fever. Four hours ago, he ate some leftover rice he had ordered the night before. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He immigrated from India 8 years ago with his family and now works as a butcher. He appears ill. His temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 115/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Abdominal examination shows diffuse mild tenderness with no rigidity, rebound, or guarding.
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Campylobacter jejuni is the most common cause of bacterial diarrhea in the USA. It commonly affects children and may lead to bloody diarrhea. It is typically transmitted by the ingestion of contaminated food (e.g., raw poultry, unpasteurized milk) or via direct contact with infected animals (e.g., dogs). However, the incubation period is a couple of days and the patient does not report having diarrhea, making infection with C. jejuni unlikely.

B) CORRECT:

Bacillus cereus is a heat-stable, spore-forming pathogen. It grows in heated food that cools down too slowly or in food that is improperly refrigerated. Reheated rice is a common source of infection. B. cereus produces enterotoxin I (emetic form), which leads to nausea and vomiting approximately 1–3 hours after ingestion. The patient ate some leftover rice and developed symptoms 2 hours later. Therefore, infection with B. cereus is the most likely diagnosis.

B. cereus also produces enterotoxin II (diarrheal form), which leads to watery diarrhea 8–16 hours after ingestion. Symptoms last for 12–24 hours. Treatment is supportive.

C) INCORRECT:

Yersinia enterocolitica causes inflammatory diarrhea (may be bloody in severe cases), typically after ingesting contaminated milk or pork. The pathogen may also cause vomiting and abdominal tenderness in the right lower quadrant, which may mimic appendicitis (“pseudoappendicitis”). The incubation period is a couple of days. This patient developed nausea and vomiting 2 hours following the ingestion of contaminated food. Therefore, an infection with Y. enterocolitica is unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli (EHEC) produces verotoxin/Shiga-like toxin that causes bloody diarrhea (known as “enterohemorrhagic colitis”) and potentially nausea and vomiting. It can affect healthy adults (typically leading to an asymptomatic infection), but mainly affects newborns and older individuals. Transmission also occurs via the ingestion of contaminated food (e.g., raw beef and vegetables, milk), but the incubation period is longer (2–10 days). If toxins become systemic, hemolytic uremic syndrome may result.

E) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus (a gram-positive bacterium) is a common cause of food poisoning. Ingestion of preformed toxins (produced by S. aureus) in contaminated poorly refrigerated food (e.g., mayonnaise) typically causes a rapid onset of illness (1–6 hours after ingestion) with nausea and vomiting. Although this patient has had potentially poorly refrigerated food, rice is most typically contaminated by another pathogen.

F) INCORRECT:

Entamoeba histolytica can cause intestinal amebiasis, which is characterized by loose stools containing mucus and bright red blood, painful defecation, abdominal pain, cramps, anorexia/weight loss, and fever. It has an incubation period of 1–4 weeks. The patient does not have diarrhea and the incubation period of his infection was 2 hours, making amebiasis unlikely.

G) INCORRECT:

The hallmarks of infection with Salmonella enteritidis infection are high-grade fever, severe vomiting, and inflammatory (watery-bloody) diarrhea. Salmonella are typically transmitted via the ingestion of contaminated food (poultry, poorly pasteurized eggs, and milk). The incubation period is 6–48 hours and is largely dependent on the bacterial load in the contaminated food.

H) INCORRECT:

Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC) produces heat-labile as well as heat-stable enterotoxins, which cause diffuse watery diarrhea associated with abdominal cramping, nausea, and possibly vomiting. ETEC has an incubation period of 9 hours to 3 days and is the most common cause of traveler's diarrhea. The vignette does not mention a recent travel history and the incubation period indicated is not fitting, meaning that an ETEC infection is unlikely.

I) INCORRECT:

Shigella dysenteriae enters the gastrointestinal tract, leading to inflammation, mucosal damage, and bloody diarrhea. It has an incubation period of 1–3 days. This patient does not have bloody diarrhea and he developed the symptoms only 2 hours following food ingestion. These findings suggest a different organism.

J) INCORRECT:

Vibrio parahaemolyticus can cause foodborne illness but typically becomes symptomatic 16–72 hours after ingestion of undercooked seafood. It is the most common cause of diarrhea in Japan. Treatment is usually supportive, but administering doxycycline or fluoroquinolones may be considered in severe cases.
questions.hint: Rapid onset of vomiting following the ingestion of a rice dish is a typical scenario seen in infection with the underlying organism.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of abdominal cramping, vomiting, and watery diarrhea for the past 4 hours. One day ago, she went to a seafood restaurant with her family to celebrate her birthday. Three of the attendees have developed similar symptoms. The patient appears lethargic. Her temperature is 38.8°C (101.8°F). Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for this patient's current symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Campylobacter jejuni causes a foodborne illness that manifests with fever, abdominal cramps, diarrhea, and, occasionally, vomiting, as seen here. Although C. jejuni is typically transmitted via undercooked poultry or unpasteurized milk, shellfish has also been implicated in some cases of Campylobacter enteritis. Patients with Campylobacter enteritis usually have bloody diarrhea, with symptoms typically beginning 2–4 days after the ingestion of contaminated food. This woman, however, presents with watery diarrhea one day after visiting a seafood restaurant.

B) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus enterotoxins cause a foodborne illness that manifests with fever, abdominal cramps, vomiting, and watery diarrhea, as seen here. However, the toxins are most commonly transmitted via processed meats, mayonnaise, custard, or nondairy creamers, not seafood. Moreover, symptoms typically begin within 1–4 hours of ingesting the contaminated food, unlike this patient's presentation one day after a restaurant visit.

C) CORRECT:

Vibrio parahaemolyticus gastroenteritis is typically caused by eating raw or undercooked shellfish (especially oysters). Patients present with fever, abdominal cramps, vomiting, and watery/bloody diarrhea 12–52 hours after ingesting the contaminated shellfish, as seen here. The infection is generally self-limiting. Other pathogens that can be transmitted through shellfish include Vibrio cholerae, Vibrio vulnificus, hepatitis A virus, hepatitis E virus, norovirus, and Paragonimus species.

D) INCORRECT:

Listeria monocytogenes causes a foodborne illness that manifests with fever, abdominal cramps, vomiting, and watery diarrhea within 6 hours to 10 days of ingesting the contaminated food. However, L. monocytogenes is typically transmitted via unpasteurized dairy products or ready-to-eat deli meats, not seafood.

E) INCORRECT:

Enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli (EHEC) causes a foodborne illness that can manifest with fever, abdominal cramps, vomiting, and diarrhea, as seen here. However, EHEC is typically transmitted via undercooked meat, unpasteurized dairy products, or fruit juices, not seafood. Moreover, patients usually have bloody diarrhea with symptoms beginning 2–10 days after ingesting contaminated food, unlike this patient who presents with watery diarrhea one day after eating at a seafood restaurant.

F) INCORRECT:

Nontyphoidal serotypes of Salmonella enterica cause foodborne illnesses that manifest with fever, abdominal cramps, vomiting, and watery diarrhea within 6–72 hours of ingesting the contaminated food. However, S. enterica is typically transmitted via undercooked eggs, poultry, or unpasteurized milk products, not seafood. Infection with typhoidal serotypes of S. enterica (e.g., S. Typhi, S. Paratyphi) causes enteric fever, which commonly begins 6–30 days after ingesting the contaminated food.

G) INCORRECT:

Bacillus cereus enterotoxins can cause two forms of foodborne illness. The emetic form manifests with abdominal cramps, vomiting, and, occasionally, watery diarrhea, as seen here. However, the emetic toxins are typically transmitted via improperly refrigerated starch products (e.g., rice) rather than seafood, and the symptoms occur within 1–3 hours of ingesting the contaminated food source. The diarrheal form has a latency period of 6–24 hours and manifests with abdominal cramps and watery diarrhea. However, vomiting would not be expected. Foods associated with diarrheal toxin-mediated disease include improperly refrigerated milk, meat, and vegetables. Fever would not be expected in either the emetic or diarrheal form of B. cereus infection.
questions.hint: The most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is a gram-negative, oxidase-positive rod.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with a 2-day history of abdominal pain and diarrhea. She has had about 8 voluminous stools per day, some of which were bloody. She went to an international food festival 3 days ago. She takes no medications. Her temperature is 39.5°C (103.1°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg. Examination shows a tender abdomen, increased bowel sounds, and dry mucous membranes. Microscopic examination of the stool shows polymorphonuclear leukocytes. Stool culture results are pending. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Reheated rice is commonly associated with infection with Bacillus cereus, which produces two different enterotoxins that can cause two distinct food poisoning syndromes: the emetic form and the diarrheal form. The emetic form is the one most commonly associated with reheated rice and manifests predominantly with nausea and vomiting rather than diarrhea. The diarrheal form is associated with a broad range of improperly refrigerated food (e.g., meat, vegetables) and typically manifests with watery rather than inflammatory diarrhea.

B) INCORRECT:

Yogurt dip would most likely be the source of Staphylococcus aureus food poisoning caused by an enterotoxin that has a very short latency period of 1–6 hours. Patients develop secretory diarrhea that manifests with nausea, vomiting, abdominal discomfort, and watery diarrhea. Resolution of symptoms occurs within 24–48 hours. Fever and leukocytes in stool would also not be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Several mushrooms cause symptoms in humans when ingested and some, like Amanita phalloides, are potentially lethal. A. phalloides produces a toxin that blocks RNA polymerase, which inhibits transcription and protein synthesis, leading to apoptosis. Patients typically present with gastrointestinal symptoms (diarrhea, vomiting, abdominal cramps) 6–24 hours after ingestion and subsequently develop toxic renal and liver failure after 2–6 days. However, this patient has no signs of organ damage, presenting instead with fever, bloody diarrhea, and leukocytes in the stool, which is indicative of inflammatory diarrhea caused by direct interaction between bacteria and mucosal lining.

D) INCORRECT:

Improperly canned foods are often the source of Clostridium botulinum, an anaerobic, gram-positive rod that forms spores and produces a heat-labile neurotoxin. Ingestion of the toxin may cause gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., gastrointestinal discomfort, nausea, and vomiting), but it would also not cause inflammatory diarrhea. Instead, dramatic neurological impairment that includes descending paralysis, dysarthria, dysphagia, and diplopia would be expected.

E) CORRECT:

This patient developed inflammatory diarrhea one day following the food festival, which is consistent with the incubation period of S. enteritidis (1–3 days). Omelets may contain undercooked eggs, which can be contaminated with S. enteritidis. Salmonella spp. are the 2nd most common pathogen responsible for bacterial foodborne gastroenteritis (the most common in the US being Campylobacter). Typical diagnostic findings are fever as well as leukocytes, blood, and/or mucus in stool due to destruction of the enteric mucosa by invasive Salmonella.
questions.hint: The patient most likely has inflammatory diarrhea (bloody stools with PMNs) caused by Salmonella enteritidis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of fever, watery diarrhea, and abdominal cramping for the past 24 hours. She recently went to an international food fair. Her temperature is 39°C (102.2°F). Physical examination shows increased bowel sounds. Stool cultures grow gram-positive, spore-forming, anaerobic rods that produce alpha toxin. The responsible organism also causes which of the following physical examination findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diffuse, flaccid bullae are seen in staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS), which is caused by Staphylococcus aureus. While these bacteria are a common cause of acute gastroenteritis, Staphylococcus aureus is a β-hemolytic, catalase-positive, gram-positive coccus that grows in clusters.

B) INCORRECT:

Facial paralysis can be observed in Guillain Barré syndrome, which may occur as a complication of Campylobacter jejuni enteritis, the most common pathogen responsible for foodborne gastroenteritis in the US. While this infection also manifests with diarrhea, it most often causes bloody diarrhea, not the watery diarrhea seen in this patient. Moreover, Campylobacter jejuni is a comma-shaped, gram-negative rod, while this patient's culture has grown gram-positive, spore-forming, anaerobic rods.

C) CORRECT:

Clostridium perfringens, the organism responsible for this patient's symptoms, can also cause gas gangrene, which classically manifests with subcutaneous emphysema and palpable crepitus. The spores of these obligate anaerobic rods survive in undercooked food; when ingested, bacteria release heat-labile enterotoxins that cause food poisoning with watery diarrhea and severe abdominal cramping. This condition is rarely complicated by a syndrome that resembles necrotizing enteritis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a bacterial culture (Gram stain; very high magnification; cultivated in Schaedler broth)

Multiple gram-positive, rod-shaped Clostridium perfringens bacteria are seen.

D) INCORRECT:

Rose spots can be caused by infection with Salmonella typhi or Salmonella paratyphi, which are transmitted via the fecal-oral route. While these organisms can cause diarrhea, (para)typhoid fever typically progresses over the course of weeks. Moreover, these organisms are gram-negative and non-spore-forming, which would not be consistent with the gram-positive, spore-forming bacteria seen in this patient's culture.
Image Description:

There are several small, bright red macules on the skin of the chest and shoulders. This skin finding is accompanied by fever.

These findings are a rare skin manifestation of typhoid fever, caused by the bacterium Salmonella enterica serovar Typhi.

E) INCORRECT:

A petechial rash can be observed in hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS), which is most commonly caused by enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC). However, EHEC typically causes bloody diarrhea, which is not present in this patient. The only type of E. coli that causes watery diarrhea is enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC), the most frequent cause of traveler's diarrhea. Since this patient has no history of recent travel, this diagnosis is also unlikely.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms and stool culture are consistent with Clostridium perfringens enterocolitis.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of abdominal cramping, profuse vomiting, and mild watery diarrhea that started about 4 hours after her lunch. Her temperature is 37.6°C (99.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 122/68 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows diffuse mild tenderness with no rigidity, rebound, or guarding. Analysis of the patient's vomitus is positive for an enterotoxin produced by a gram-positive, coagulase-positive coccus. Which of the following measures is most likely to have prevented this patient's current symptoms?

choices.text: Enforce proper hand-washing for food handlers
Cook meats to core temperature of 60°C

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Avoiding reheated rice decreases the risk of infection with Bacillus cereus, which is an enterotoxin-producing, gram-positive rod, not a coccus. Additionally, B. cereus produces two different enterotoxins that can cause two distinct food poisoning syndromes: the emetic form and the diarrheal form. The emetic form is caused by heat-stable cereulide toxin. Because the toxin survives reheating, this form is commonly associated with reheated starch-containing foods (e.g., rice) and manifests shortly after ingestion predominantly with nausea and vomiting, not diarrhea. The diarrheal form is caused by heat-labile enterotoxin II and is associated with a broad range of improperly refrigerated food (e.g., meat, vegetables). This form typically manifests with abdominal pain and watery diarrhea a couple of hours after ingestion of contaminated food. This patient's constellation of symptoms and microbiological findings suggests a different pathogen.

B) INCORRECT:

Disposing of spoiled dark-meat fish reduces the risk of scombroid poisoning, which can manifest with abdominal cramping, vomiting, and diarrhea, which this patient has. However, patients typically also present with symptoms of excessive histamine intake, like flushing or erythema on the face, neck, or upper torso, headache, dizziness, blurry vision, perioral paraesthesias (e.g., burning or itching), and/or cardiorespiratory symptoms (e.g., tachycardia or palpitations), none of which is seen in this case.

Spoiled fish associated with scombroid poisoning can also be contaminated with bacteria (i.e., Escherichia coli, Vibrio species, Proteus, Klebsiella, Clostridium, Salmonella, or Shigella), but none of them produce an enterotoxin.

C) CORRECT:

Proper handwashing during food preparation is the most effective strategy for reducing the risk of Staphylococcus aureus gastroenteritis, which manifests with acute vomiting, abdominal pain, and diarrhea after consuming food contaminated with enterotoxins. The bacteria typically proliferate in inadequately refrigerated food (e.g., dairy, meats, eggs, salads), which leads to the production of enterotoxins. Although S. aureus is destroyed during cooking, the heat-stable enterotoxins are not. Because these enterotoxins are preformed, symptoms usually manifest within 1–6 hours of consuming contaminated food. Management includes supportive care with appropriate hydration; symptoms typically self-resolve within 24–48 hours.

D) INCORRECT:

Cooking meats to a high temperature decreases the risk of most food-related infections such as enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC) gastroenteritis, which is caused by heat-labile enterotoxin. Because symptoms are caused by preformed toxins, affected individuals usually present with vomiting, abdominal pain, and/or watery diarrhea within 1 to 6 hours after consuming contaminated food, as seen in this patient. However, the preformed toxins found in this patient are produced by gram-positive cocci, not gram-negative rods.

E) INCORRECT:

Thoroughly rinsing vegetables reduces the risk of shigellosis, which manifests with high fever, tenesmus, and profuse inflammatory mucoid-bloody diarrhea, none of which is seen in this patient. Shigellosis is caused by endotoxin/exotoxin-producing strains of Shigella bacteria (e.g., S. dysenteriae, S. flexneri), which can be found in unpasteurized milk products and raw unwashed vegetables. Symptoms usually develop within 1–3 days; treatment includes support measures (e.g., hydration, electrolyte replacement) and antibiotic therapy.
questions.hint: This patient most likely has food poisoning due to ingestion of enterotoxin B.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 1-day history of passing small quantities of dark urine. Two weeks ago, he had fever, abdominal pain, and bloody diarrhea for several days that were treated with oral antibiotics. Physical examination shows pale conjunctivae and scleral icterus. His hemoglobin concentration is 7.5 g/dL, platelet count is 95,000/mm3, and serum creatinine concentration is 1.9 mg/dL. A peripheral blood smear shows irregular red blood cell fragments. Avoiding consumption of which of the following foods would have most likely prevented this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Reheated rice can transmit heat-stable spores produced by Bacillus cereus. When these spores germinate, they form toxins that cause two forms of food poisoning, an emetic form and a diarrheal form with predominantly watery (not bloody) diarrhea. However, B. cereus infection is not associated with hemolytic uremic syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Mushroom poisoning can result in several syndromes, some of which manifest with diarrhea. However, mushroom poisoning syndromes are not associated with hemolytic uremic syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Shellfish can transmit Vibrio vulnificus, Vibrio parahaemolyticus, and hepatitis A virus. These pathogens cause diarrhea, which can be bloody in the case of V. parahaemolyticus infection, but are not associated with hemolytic uremic syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Consumption of undercooked pork can cause trichinosis and yersiniosis. Both of these conditions cause diarrhea but are not associated with hemolytic uremic syndrome.

E) CORRECT:

Undercooked beef is a common source of E. coli O157:H7 infection, which most frequently spreads via contaminated foods. The gastrointestinal tract of cattle is a reservoir for the causative bacteria. Contamination of raw leafy vegetables with cattle feces and unpasteurized milk have also been linked to outbreaks of infection. Less frequently, the infection spreads from person-to-person transmission, especially in daycare centers. HUS most commonly affects children < 5 years of age.

F) INCORRECT:

Improperly canned food can transmit spores produced by Clostridium botulinum. These spores cause foodborne botulism but are not associated with hemolytic uremic syndrome. While transmission of EHEC via contaminated vegetables is possible, this is limited to fresh leafy vegetables such as lettuce or spinach, not canned carrots.

G) INCORRECT:

Undercooked eggs can transmit nontyphoidal Salmonella, which causes diarrhea that can occasionally be bloody. However, nontyphoidal Salmonella infection is not associated with hemolytic uremic syndrome.
questions.hint: This child has hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS), which causes thrombocytopenia, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (which manifests with schistocytes seen on peripheral blood smear), and acute kidney injury. HUS most commonly occurs after infection with Shiga-like toxin-producing enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) strain O157:H7.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old man has had fever, malaise, and watery stools without blood or mucus for the past 2 days. Four days ago, he attended a barbecue and ate grilled chicken. He has not traveled recently or used any antibiotics.
On examination, his temperature is 38°C. He is in mild distress. His abdomen is soft with diffuse mild tenderness. Bowel sounds are present.
Which one of the following infections is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Shigella produces a toxin that invades the colonic mucosa, and symptoms usually consist of bloody diarrhea with mucus. The incubation period is quite short, with a mean time of 3 days. It may be foodborne or transmitted from person to person.

B) CORRECT:

The most common causes of acute diarrheal infection related to bacterial pathogens in the United States are Campylobacter jejuni, non-typhi Salmonella species, Shigella, and toxigenic Escherichia coli. Clues to etiology include quality of diarrhea (presence or absence of blood and/or mucus) as well as time to onset of symptoms.

Infection with C. jejuni is not toxin-mediated; thus, the symptoms, which include fever, diarrhea, and abdominal cramping, tend to be delayed for 2 to 5 days from the time of exposure, as in this case. The infection tends to be community acquired and foodborne, most typically from the handling or ingestion of undercooked poultry.

Because of rising rates of fluoroquinolone resistance, macrolides (such as azithromycin) are usually considered first-line therapy for C. jejuni infection, particularly when the infection is acquired after travel to countries that have high rates of fluoroquinolone resistance, such as Thailand.

Salmonella enteritidis (not S. typhimurium) is also a foodborne cause of diarrhea. The incubation period is shorter than Shigella and Campylobacter, generally 8 to 72 hours, and the patient usually has bloody diarrhea with mucus.

Key learning point: A common bacterial cause of acute infectious diarrhea associated with undercooked poultry is Campylobacter jejuni.

C) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcal food poisoning is the most unlikely cause of diarrhea in this patient because the bacterium produces a preformed toxin, and the onset of illness is usually very rapid, within 24 hours. Fever is very uncommon, and once the toxin is eliminated, the patient starts to improve rapidly. Vomiting is a frequent symptom along with diarrhea.

D) INCORRECT:

Bacillus cereus, a spore-forming gram-positive organism, can cause foodborne diarrheal infection due to a preformed and heat-stable toxin. The ingested preformed toxin results in symptoms within hours of exposure, which is not consistent with the clinical timeline in this case.

E) INCORRECT:

Yersinia enterocolitica is an unusual cause of diarrhea. Symptoms are similar to those seen with Salmonella and Shigella (abdominal cramping and diarrhea), but the onset is often less acute and less severe. A clue to Y. enterocolitica infection can be right-lower-quadrant pain, causing clinical concern for appendicitis.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old boy has had fever, malaise, and watery stools without blood or mucus for the past 2 days. Four days ago, he attended a barbecue and ate grilled chicken. He has not traveled recently or used any antibiotics.
On examination, his temperature is 38°C. He is in mild distress. His abdomen is soft with diffuse mild tenderness. Bowel sounds are present.
Which one of the following infections is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bacillus cereus, a spore-forming gram-positive organism, can cause foodborne diarrheal infection due to a preformed and heat-stable toxin. The ingested preformed toxin results in symptoms within hours of exposure, which is not consistent with the clinical timeline in this case.

B) CORRECT:

The most common causes of acute diarrheal infection related to bacterial pathogens in the United States are Campylobacter jejuni, non-typhi Salmonella species, Shigella, and toxigenic Escherichia coli. Clues to etiology include quality of diarrhea (presence or absence of blood and/or mucus) as well as time to onset of symptoms.

Infection with C. jejuni is not toxin-mediated; thus, the symptoms, which include fever, diarrhea, and abdominal cramping, tend to be delayed for 2 to 5 days from the time of exposure, as in this case. The infection tends to be community-acquired and foodborne, most typically from the handling or ingestion of undercooked poultry.

Because of rising rates of fluoroquinolone resistance, macrolides (such as azithromycin) are usually considered first-line therapy for C. jejuni infection, particularly when the infection is acquired after travel to countries that have high rates of fluoroquinolone resistance (typically because of antibiotic exposure of poultry and cattle).

Shigella produces a toxin that invades the colonic mucosa, and symptoms usually consist of bloody diarrhea with mucus. The incubation period is quite short, with a mean time of 3 days. It may be foodborne or transmitted from person to person.

Salmonella enteritidis (not S. typhimurium) is also a foodborne cause of diarrhea. The incubation period is shorter than Shigella and Campylobacter, generally 8 to 72 hours, and the patient usually has bloody diarrhea with mucus.

Key learning point: A common bacterial cause of acute infectious diarrhea associated with undercooked poultry is Campylobacter jejuni.

C) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcal food poisoning is the most unlikely cause of diarrhea in this patient because the bacterium produces a preformed toxin, and the onset of illness is usually very rapid, within 24 hours. Fever is very uncommon, and once the toxin is eliminated, the patient starts to improve rapidly. Vomiting is a frequent symptom along with diarrhea.

D) INCORRECT:

Yersinia enterocolitica is an unusual cause of diarrhea. Symptoms are similar to those seen with Salmonella and Shigella (abdominal cramping and diarrhea), but the onset is often less acute and less severe. A clue to Y. enterocolitica infection can be right-lower-quadrant pain, causing clinical concern for appendicitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Shigella produces a toxin that invades the colonic mucosa, and symptoms usually consist of bloody diarrhea with mucus. The incubation period is quite short, with a mean time of 3 days. It may be foodborne or transmitted from person to person.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man has had fever, malaise, and watery stools without blood or mucus for the past 2 days. Four days ago, he attended a barbecue and ate grilled chicken. He has not traveled recently or used any antibiotics. On examination, his temperature is 38°C (100.4°F). He is in mild distress. His abdomen is soft with diffuse mild tenderness. Bowel sounds are present. Which of the following infections is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Shigella produces a toxin that invades the colonic mucosa, and symptoms usually consist of bloody diarrhea with mucus. The incubation period is quite short, with a mean time of 3 days. It may be foodborne or transmitted from person to person.

B) CORRECT:

The most common causes of acute diarrheal infection related to bacterial pathogens in the United States are Campylobacter jejuni, non-typhi Salmonella species, Shigella, and toxigenic Escherichia coli. Clues to etiology include quality of diarrhea (presence or absence of blood and/or mucus) as well as time to onset of symptoms.

Infection with C. jejuni is not toxin-mediated; thus, the symptoms, which include fever, diarrhea, and abdominal cramping, tend to be delayed for 2 to 5 days from the time of exposure, as in this case. The infection tends to be community acquired and foodborne, most typically from the handling or ingestion of undercooked poultry.

Because of rising rates of fluoroquinolone resistance, macrolides (such as azithromycin) are usually considered first-line therapy for C. jejuni infection, particularly when the infection is acquired after travel to countries that have high rates of fluoroquinolone resistance, such as Thailand.

Salmonella enteritidis (not S. typhimurium) is also a foodborne cause of diarrhea. The incubation period is shorter than Shigella and Campylobacter, generally 8 to 72 hours, and the patient usually has bloody diarrhea with mucus.

Key learning point: A common bacterial cause of acute infectious diarrhea associated with undercooked poultry is Campylobacter jejuni.

C) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcal food poisoning is the most unlikely cause of diarrhea in this patient because the bacterium produces a preformed toxin, and the onset of illness is usually very rapid, within 24 hours. Fever is very uncommon, and once the toxin is eliminated, the patient starts to improve rapidly. Vomiting is a frequent symptom along with diarrhea.

D) INCORRECT:

Bacillus cereus, a spore-forming gram-positive organism, can cause foodborne diarrheal infection due to a preformed and heat-stable toxin. The ingested preformed toxin results in symptoms within hours of exposure, which is not consistent with the clinical timeline in this case.

E) INCORRECT:

Yersinia enterocolitica is an unusual cause of diarrhea. Symptoms are similar to those seen with Salmonella and Shigella (abdominal cramping and diarrhea), but the onset is often less acute and less severe. A clue to Y. enterocolitica infection can be right-lower-quadrant pain, causing clinical concern for appendicitis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with a 2-day history of abdominal pain and diarrhea. She has had about 8 voluminous stools per day, some of which were bloody. She went to an international food festival 3 days ago. She takes no medications. Her temperature is 39.5°C (103.1°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg. Examination shows a tender abdomen, increased bowel sounds, and dry mucous membranes. Microscopic examination of the stool shows polymorphonuclear leukocytes. Stool culture results are pending. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Reheated rice is commonly associated with infection with Bacillus cereus, which produces two different enterotoxins that can cause two distinct food poisoning syndromes: the emetic form and the diarrheal form. The emetic form is the one most commonly associated with reheated rice and manifests predominantly with nausea and vomiting rather than diarrhea. The diarrheal form is associated with a broad range of improperly refrigerated food (e.g., meat, vegetables) and typically manifests with watery rather than inflammatory diarrhea.

B) INCORRECT:

Yogurt dip would most likely be the source of Staphylococcus aureus food poisoning caused by an enterotoxin that has a very short latency period of 1–6 hours. Patients develop secretory diarrhea that manifests with nausea, vomiting, abdominal discomfort, and watery diarrhea. Resolution of symptoms occurs within 24–48 hours. Fever and leukocytes in stool would also not be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Several mushrooms cause symptoms in humans when ingested and some, like Amanita phalloides, are potentially lethal. A. phalloides produces a toxin that blocks RNA polymerase, which inhibits transcription and protein synthesis, leading to apoptosis. Patients typically present with gastrointestinal symptoms (diarrhea, vomiting, abdominal cramps) 6–24 hours after ingestion and subsequently develop toxic renal and liver failure after 2–6 days. However, this patient has no signs of organ damage, presenting instead with fever, bloody diarrhea, and leukocytes in the stool, which is indicative of inflammatory diarrhea caused by direct interaction between bacteria and mucosal lining.

D) INCORRECT:

Improperly canned foods are often the source of Clostridium botulinum, an anaerobic, gram-positive rod that forms spores and produces a heat-labile neurotoxin. Ingestion of the toxin may cause gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., gastrointestinal discomfort, nausea, and vomiting), but it would also not cause inflammatory diarrhea. Instead, dramatic neurological impairment that includes descending paralysis, dysarthria, dysphagia, and diplopia would be expected.

E) CORRECT:

This patient developed inflammatory diarrhea one day following the food festival, which is consistent with the incubation period of S. enteritidis (1–3 days). Undercooked eggs can be contaminated with S. enteritidis. Salmonella spp. are the 2nd most common pathogen responsible for bacterial foodborne gastroenteritis (the most common in the US being Campylobacter). Typical diagnostic findings are fever as well as leukocytes, blood, and/or mucus in stool due to destruction of the enteric mucosa by invasive Salmonella.

The primary treatment for salmonella gastroenteritis involves supportive care, including a bland diet and oral rehydration therapy. Antibiotic therapy is reserved for severe cases of nontyphoidal Salmonella infections because it can prolong fecal excretion of the pathogen.
questions.hint: The patient most likely has inflammatory diarrhea (bloody stools with PMNs) caused by Salmonella enteritidis.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the office because of a 1-day history of passing small quantities of dark urine. Two weeks ago, he had fever, abdominal pain, and bloody diarrhea for several days that were treated with oral antibiotics. Physical examination shows pale conjunctivae and scleral icterus. His hemoglobin concentration is 7.5 g/dL, platelet count is 95,000/mm3, and serum creatinine concentration is 1.9 mg/dL. A peripheral blood smear shows irregular red blood cell fragments. Avoiding consumption of which of the following foods would have most likely prevented this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Reheated rice can transmit heat-stable spores produced by Bacillus cereus. When these spores germinate, they form toxins that cause two forms of food poisoning, an emetic form and a diarrheal form with predominantly watery (not bloody) diarrhea. However, B. cereus infection is not associated with hemolytic uremic syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Shellfish can transmit Vibrio vulnificus, Vibrio parahaemolyticus, and hepatitis A virus. These pathogens cause diarrhea, which can be bloody in the case of V. parahaemolyticus infection, but are not associated with hemolytic uremic syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Consumption of undercooked pork can cause trichinosis and yersiniosis. Both of these conditions cause diarrhea but are not associated with hemolytic uremic syndrome.

D) CORRECT:

Undercooked beef is a common source of E. coli O157:H7 infection, which most frequently spreads via contaminated foods. The gastrointestinal tract of cattle is a reservoir for the causative bacteria. Contamination of raw leafy vegetables with cattle feces and unpasteurized milk have also been linked to outbreaks of infection. Less frequently, the infection spreads from person-to-person transmission, especially in daycare centers. HUS most commonly affects children < 5 years of age.

E) INCORRECT:

Undercooked eggs can transmit nontyphoidal Salmonella, which causes diarrhea that can occasionally be bloody. However, nontyphoidal Salmonella infection is not associated with hemolytic uremic syndrome.
questions.hint: This child has hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS), which causes thrombocytopenia, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (which manifests with schistocytes seen on peripheral blood smear), and acute kidney injury. HUS most commonly occurs after infection with Shiga-like toxin-producing enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) strain O157:H7.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old woman attends a large family gathering in the middle of summer. She eats homemade potato salad that has been left out for several hours. Two hours later, she develops severe nausea, repeated vomiting, and crampy abdominal pain. She has no fever or bloody stools. Physical examination reveals mild dehydration with stable vital signs. Laboratory testing shows no leukocytosis.
Which of the following is the most likely explanation for her acute gastrointestinal symptoms?

choices.text: Toxin production by spore-forming Clostridium in the colon
Parasite requiring intracellular replication in the small intestine
Bacterial invasion of intestinal mucosa by Salmonella

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Staphylococcal food poisoning results from ingesting preformed enterotoxins produced by Staphylococcus aureus in improperly stored foods, such as potato salad. These toxins are heat-stable and cause rapid onset of symptoms, including severe nausea, vomiting, and crampy abdominal pain, typically within hours. The absence of fever, bloody stools, or leukocytosis supports a toxin-mediated process rather than an invasive infection.

Key learning point: Staphylococcus aureus food poisoning is characterized by rapid onset of symptoms (within 1-6 hours) due to ingestion of preformed enterotoxins.

B) INCORRECT:

Clostridium perfringens food poisoning involves toxin production in the colon, requiring an 8-16 hour incubation period. It typically presents with watery diarrhea and less vomiting. The rapid onset of symptoms within two hours, characterized by severe nausea and vomiting, suggests ingestion of preformed toxins rather than in vivo toxin production.

C) INCORRECT:

Parasites that require intracellular replication, such as Cryptosporidium, have longer incubation periods, often days to weeks, and typically cause prolonged diarrhea rather than rapid-onset vomiting. The rapid symptom onset and absence of fever or leukocytosis suggest a toxin-mediated process, not a parasitic infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Salmonella gastroenteritis usually presents with a longer incubation period (6-48 hours), fever, and diarrhea, often with leukocytosis. The rapid onset of symptoms within two hours, without fever or leukocytosis, aligns more with a toxin-mediated process than an invasive bacterial infection.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with sudden onset of nausea and repeated vomiting approximately three hours after eating potato salad at an outdoor barbecue. He has no diarrhea or fever. Several friends who ate the same dish have similar symptoms. Examination shows mild abdominal tenderness.
Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Clostridium perfringens typically causes symptoms 8–16 hours after ingestion, with diarrhea and abdominal cramps being more common than vomiting. The rapid onset and emetic symptoms in this case are inconsistent with Clostridium perfringens.

B) INCORRECT:

Salmonella enterica usually causes symptoms 12 to 72 hours after ingestion, including diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and fever. The rapid onset of nausea and vomiting without diarrhea or fever in this case is not typical for Salmonella enterica.

C) CORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus causes food poisoning through ingestion of preformed, heat-stable enterotoxins. These toxins, produced when foods like potato salad are left at room temperature, trigger nausea and vomiting within 1 to 6 hours. The absence of fever is typical, as the symptoms result from a toxin-mediated response rather than an invasive infection.

Key learning point: Rapid onset of vomiting within hours of eating is typically due to preformed toxins, with Staphylococcus aureus being a common cause.

D) INCORRECT:

Bacillus cereus can cause an emetic syndrome with nausea and vomiting 1–6 hours after ingestion of a preformed toxin. However, this syndrome is typically associated with reheated rice, not potato salad, making it less likely in this context.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 4-hour history of abdominal cramping, vomiting, and watery diarrhea. She ate at a seafood restaurant with her family one day ago, and three other attendees have developed similar symptoms. She appears lethargic. Her temperature is 38.8°C. Which one of the following organisms is most likely responsible for her current symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Campylobacter jejuni causes a foodborne illness that manifests with fever, abdominal cramps, diarrhea, and, occasionally, vomiting, as seen here. Although C. jejuni is typically transmitted via undercooked poultry or unpasteurized milk, shellfish has also been implicated in some cases of Campylobacter enteritis. Patients with Campylobacter enteritis usually have bloody diarrhea, with symptoms typically beginning 2–4 days after the ingestion of contaminated food. This woman, however, presents with watery diarrhea one day after visiting a seafood restaurant.

B) INCORRECT:

Nontyphoidal serotypes of Salmonella enterica cause foodborne illnesses that manifest with fever, abdominal cramps, vomiting, and watery diarrhea within 6–72 hours of ingesting the contaminated food. However, S. enterica is typically transmitted via undercooked eggs, poultry, or unpasteurized milk products, not seafood. Infection with typhoidal serotypes of S. enterica (e.g., S. Typhi, S. Paratyphi) causes enteric fever, which commonly begins 6–30 days after ingesting the contaminated food.

C) CORRECT:

Vibrio parahaemolyticus gastroenteritis is typically caused by eating raw or undercooked shellfish (especially oysters). Patients present with fever, abdominal cramps, vomiting, and watery/bloody diarrhea 12–52 hours after ingesting the contaminated shellfish, as seen here. The infection is generally self-limiting. Other pathogens that can be transmitted through shellfish include Vibrio cholerae, Vibrio vulnificus, hepatitis A virus, hepatitis E virus, norovirus, and Paragonimus species.

Key learning point: Vibrio parahaemolyticus causes acute gastroenteritis after ingestion of raw or undercooked shellfish, especially oysters, and typically presents with fever, abdominal cramps, vomiting, and watery diarrhea within 12–52 hours.

D) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus enterotoxins cause a foodborne illness that manifests with fever, abdominal cramps, vomiting, and watery diarrhea, as seen here. However, the toxins are most commonly transmitted via processed meats, mayonnaise, custard, or nondairy creamers, not seafood. Moreover, symptoms typically begin within 1–4 hours of ingesting the contaminated food, unlike this patient's presentation one day after a restaurant visit.

E) INCORRECT:

Listeria monocytogenes causes a foodborne illness that manifests with fever, abdominal cramps, vomiting, and watery diarrhea within 6 hours to 10 days of ingesting the contaminated food. However, L. monocytogenes is typically transmitted via unpasteurized dairy products or ready-to-eat deli meats, not seafood.
questions.hint: The most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is a gram-negative, oxidase-positive rod.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 2-day history of fever, malaise, and watery stools without blood or mucus. Four days ago, he attended a barbecue where he ate grilled chicken. He has not traveled recently and has not used any antibiotics. On examination, his temperature is 38°C. He appears mildly distressed. His abdomen is soft with diffuse mild tenderness, and bowel sounds are present. Which one of the following infections is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The most common causes of acute diarrheal infection related to bacterial pathogens in the United States are Campylobacter jejuni, non-typhi Salmonella species, Shigella, and toxigenic Escherichia coli. Clues to etiology include quality of diarrhea (presence or absence of blood and/or mucus) as well as time to onset of symptoms.

Infection with C. jejuni is not toxin-mediated; thus, the symptoms, which include fever, diarrhea, and abdominal cramping, tend to be delayed for 2 to 5 days from the time of exposure, as in this case. The infection tends to be community acquired and foodborne, most typically from the handling or ingestion of undercooked poultry.

Because of rising rates of fluoroquinolone resistance, macrolides (such as azithromycin) are usually considered first-line therapy for C. jejuni infection, particularly when the infection is acquired after travel to countries that have high rates of fluoroquinolone resistance, such as Thailand.

Salmonella enteritidis (not S. typhimurium) is also a foodborne cause of diarrhea. The incubation period is shorter than Shigella and Campylobacter, generally 8 to 72 hours, and the patient usually has bloody diarrhea with mucus.

Key learning point: A common bacterial cause of acute infectious diarrhea associated with undercooked poultry is Campylobacter jejuni.

B) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcal food poisoning is the most unlikely cause of diarrhea in this patient because the bacterium produces a preformed toxin, and the onset of illness is usually very rapid, within 24 hours. Fever is very uncommon, and once the toxin is eliminated, the patient starts to improve rapidly. Vomiting is a frequent symptom along with diarrhea.

C) INCORRECT:

Bacillus cereus, a spore-forming gram-positive organism, can cause foodborne diarrheal infection due to a preformed and heat-stable toxin. The ingested preformed toxin results in symptoms within hours of exposure, which is not consistent with the clinical timeline in this case.

D) INCORRECT:

Shigella produces a toxin that invades the colonic mucosa, and symptoms usually consist of bloody diarrhea with mucus. The incubation period is quite short, with a mean time of 3 days. It may be foodborne or transmitted from person to person.

E) INCORRECT:

Yersinia enterocolitica is an unusual cause of diarrhea. Symptoms are similar to those seen with Salmonella and Shigella (abdominal cramping and diarrhea), but the onset is often less acute and less severe. A clue to Y. enterocolitica infection can be right-lower-quadrant pain, causing clinical concern for appendicitis.

questions.text: You are seeing a 32-year-old woman in the emergency department with a 2-day history of abdominal pain and diarrhea. She reports having about 8 large-volume stools per day, some of which are bloody. She attended an international food festival 3 days ago. She does not take any medications. Her temperature is 39.5°C, pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg. On examination, her abdomen is tender with increased bowel sounds, and she has dry mucous membranes. Microscopic examination of the stool reveals polymorphonuclear leukocytes. Stool culture results are pending. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Improperly canned foods are often the source of Clostridium botulinum, an anaerobic, gram-positive rod that forms spores and produces a heat-labile neurotoxin. Ingestion of the toxin may cause gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., gastrointestinal discomfort, nausea, and vomiting), but it would also not cause inflammatory diarrhea. Instead, dramatic neurological impairment that includes descending paralysis, dysarthria, dysphagia, and diplopia would be expected.

B) INCORRECT:

Several mushrooms cause symptoms in humans when ingested and some, like Amanita phalloides, are potentially lethal. A. phalloides produces a toxin that blocks RNA polymerase, which inhibits transcription and protein synthesis, leading to apoptosis. Patients typically present with gastrointestinal symptoms (diarrhea, vomiting, abdominal cramps) 6–24 hours after ingestion and subsequently develop toxic renal and liver failure after 2–6 days. However, this patient has no signs of organ damage, presenting instead with fever, bloody diarrhea, and leukocytes in the stool, which is indicative of inflammatory diarrhea caused by direct interaction between bacteria and mucosal lining.

C) INCORRECT:

Yogurt dip would most likely be the source of Staphylococcus aureus food poisoning caused by an enterotoxin that has a very short latency period of 1–6 hours. Patients develop secretory diarrhea that manifests with nausea, vomiting, abdominal discomfort, and watery diarrhea. Resolution of symptoms occurs within 24–48 hours. Fever and leukocytes in the stool would also not be expected.

D) INCORRECT:

Reheated rice is commonly associated with infection with Bacillus cereus, which produces two different enterotoxins that can cause two distinct food poisoning syndromes: the emetic form and the diarrheal form. The emetic form is the one most commonly associated with reheated rice and manifests predominantly with nausea and vomiting rather than diarrhea. The diarrheal form is associated with a broad range of improperly refrigerated food (e.g., meat, vegetables) and typically manifests with watery rather than inflammatory diarrhea.

E) CORRECT:

This patient developed inflammatory diarrhea one day following the food festival, which is consistent with the incubation period of S. enteritidis (1–3 days). Undercooked eggs can be contaminated with S. enteritidis. Nontyphoidal Salmonella spp. are the 2nd most common pathogen responsible for bacterial foodborne gastroenteritis (the most common in Canada being Campylobacter). Typical diagnostic findings are fever as well as leukocytes, blood, and/or mucus in stool due to destruction of the enteric mucosa by invasive Salmonella.

The primary treatment for salmonella gastroenteritis involves supportive care, including a bland diet and oral rehydration therapy. Antibiotic therapy is reserved for severe cases of nontyphoidal Salmonella infections because it can prolong fecal excretion of the pathogen.

Key learning point: Salmonella enteritidis from undercooked eggs commonly causes inflammatory diarrhea with fever, bloody stools, and fecal leukocytes due to mucosal invasion.
questions.hint: The patient most likely has inflammatory diarrhea (bloody stools with PMNs) caused by Salmonella enteritidis.

questions.text: You are seeing a 4-year-old boy who is brought to your clinic with a 1-day history of passing small amounts of dark urine. Two weeks ago, he had fever, abdominal pain, and several days of bloody diarrhea, which was treated with oral antibiotics. On examination, he has pale conjunctivae and scleral icterus. His hemoglobin is 75 g/L (115–155), platelet count is 95 × 109/L (130–380), and serum creatinine is 168 μmol/L (22–75). A peripheral blood smear shows irregular red blood cell fragments. Which one of the following foods, if avoided, would have most likely prevented this condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Consumption of undercooked pork can cause trichinosis and yersiniosis. Both of these conditions cause diarrhea but are not associated with hemolytic uremic syndrome.

B) CORRECT:

Undercooked beef is a common source of E. coli O157:H7 infection, which most frequently spreads via contaminated foods. The gastrointestinal tract of cattle is a reservoir for the causative bacteria. Contamination of raw leafy vegetables with cattle feces and unpasteurized milk have also been linked to outbreaks of infection. Less frequently, the infection spreads from person-to-person transmission, especially in daycare centers. HUS most commonly affects children < 5 years of age.

Key learning point: Hemolytic uremic syndrome in children is most commonly caused by Shiga toxin–producing E. coli O157:H7, often acquired from eating undercooked beef.

C) INCORRECT:

Undercooked eggs can transmit nontyphoidal Salmonella, which causes diarrhea that can occasionally be bloody. However, nontyphoidal Salmonella infection is not associated with hemolytic uremic syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Reheated rice can transmit heat-stable spores produced by Bacillus cereus. When these spores germinate, they form toxins that cause two forms of food poisoning, an emetic form and a diarrheal form with predominantly watery (not bloody) diarrhea. However, B. cereus infection is not associated with hemolytic uremic syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Shellfish can transmit Vibrio vulnificus, Vibrio parahaemolyticus, and hepatitis A virus. These pathogens cause diarrhea, which can be bloody in the case of V. parahaemolyticus infection, but are not associated with hemolytic uremic syndrome.
questions.hint: This child has hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS), which causes thrombocytopenia, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (which manifests with schistocytes seen on peripheral blood smear), and acute kidney injury. HUS most commonly occurs after infection with Shiga-like toxin-producing enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) strain O157:H7.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe nausea, vomiting, and abdominal cramping that began 2 hours after eating at a company picnic. He reports no fever or bloody stools. His symptoms started abruptly, and he has had minimal diarrhea. Vital signs are BP, 118/72; P, 102. He appears mildly dehydrated. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain CBC and comprehensive metabolic panel

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's clinical presentation suggests toxin-mediated food poisoning with rapid onset of vomiting and mild dehydration. The mainstay of treatment is supportive care with oral rehydration therapy. Most cases are self-limited and resolve within 24–48 hours.

B) INCORRECT:

CT is not indicated for typical food poisoning. This patient's clinical history and physical examination findings are consistent with toxin-mediated food poisoning.

C) INCORRECT:

Antibiotics are not indicated in patients with uncomplicated food poisoning. The rapid onset suggests preformed toxin ingestion rather than active bacterial infection, and antibiotics have no effect on preformed toxins.

D) INCORRECT:

Stool culture is not routinely indicated in food poisoning cases unless symptoms are severe, prolonged, or systemic. The rapid onset and predominant vomiting pattern suggests toxin-mediated food poisoning rather than infectious gastroenteritis.

E) INCORRECT:

Laboratory studies are not routinely required unless symptoms are severe or prolonged or systemic complications are suspected. The patient's stable vital signs and typical features of food poisoning do not warrant immediate laboratory evaluation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old restaurant patron presents to the emergency department 25 minutes after consuming a tuna steak that had been left at room temperature for several hours before preparation. She reports facial warmth, generalized pruritus, and a metallic taste in her mouth. Her dining companion, who ate salmon, remains asymptomatic. Vital signs are T, 37.0°C (98.6°F); P, 98; BP, 124/78; oxygen saturation, 98% on room air. Physical examination shows facial erythema and scattered urticarial lesions on the torso. Which medication should be administered first?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Epinephrine is reserved for severe histamine fish poisoning with signs of anaphylaxis-like reactions including hypotension, bronchospasm, or respiratory distress. This patient has normal vital signs and no respiratory symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Activated charcoal is an ineffective treatment for histamine fish poisoning because the histamine is already formed in the fish tissue and rapidly absorbed after ingestion.

C) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids such as prednisone are not first-line therapy for histamine fish poisoning. This patient's reaction is not caused by an immunological response.

D) INCORRECT:

Albuterol would be indicated if the patient developed bronchospasm or respiratory symptoms as part of a severe reaction, but this patient has no respiratory symptoms or wheezing on examination.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has histamine fish poisoning based on the rapid onset after eating improperly stored tuna, facial flushing, urticaria. The first-line treatment for mild to moderate symptoms is antihistamines such as diphenhydramine.

questions.text: A 28-year-old restaurant worker presents to the emergency department 3 hours after consuming leftover potato salad during her shift. She reports sudden onset nausea, multiple episodes of vomiting, and crampy abdominal pain. Vital signs show temperature 37.1°C, heart rate 102 bpm, blood pressure 108/68 mmHg, and oxygen saturation 99% on room air. Physical examination reveals dry mucous membranes, decreased skin turgor, and diffuse abdominal tenderness without guarding or rebound. She has not been able to keep fluids down for the past 2 hours. What is the most appropriate initial intervention?

choices.text: Obtain comprehensive metabolic panel and blood cultures

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Laboratory testing and blood cultures are not routinely indicated for typical food poisoning presentations. 

B) INCORRECT:

Antibiotics are not recommended for food poisoning as symptoms result from preformed toxins rather than active bacterial infection.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient demonstrates moderate dehydration with inability to tolerate oral fluids, requiring intravenous fluid resuscitation. IV ondansetron is appropriate to control vomiting and allow for subsequent oral intake. The combination addresses both the dehydration and the underlying symptom preventing oral rehydration.

D) INCORRECT:

Imaging studies are not indicated for straightforward food poisoning presentations. The clinical timeline and symptom pattern are consistent with toxin-mediated illness requiring supportive management rather than diagnostic imaging.

E) INCORRECT:

Nasogastric decompression is not a standard intervention for food poisoning management. The primary therapeutic focus should be on correcting dehydration and providing antiemetic therapy.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with diabetes presents to the emergency department with nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea that began 6 hours after eating leftover seafood. He reports 10 episodes of watery diarrhea and has vomited 8 times. Vital signs show mild tachycardia. Physical examination reveals dry mucous membranes, decreased skin turgor, and diffuse abdominal tenderness. After receiving appropriate supportive care, he continues to vomit and cannot tolerate oral fluids. Which of the following is the most appropriate disposition?

choices.text: Discharge home with oral rehydration solution
Hospital admission for intravenous fluid therapy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

his patient demonstrates clinical signs of moderate dehydration and persistent inability to tolerate oral fluids despite antiemetic treatment. Discharge with oral rehydration would be inappropriate as he cannot maintain adequate oral intake.

B) INCORRECT:

Additional antiemetic prescriptions would not address the underlying problem of dehydration and inability to maintain oral intake. This patient requires continued intravenous support and monitoring that cannot be provided in the outpatient setting.

C) INCORRECT:

Brief observation may be insufficient given this patient's persistent symptoms despite initial treatment and evidence of moderate dehydration.

D) INCORRECT:

Food poisoning is caused by preformed toxins rather than active bacterial infection, making antibiotics unnecessary.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient meets criteria for hospital admission and IV fluid therapy as he is unable to tolerate oral liquids despite treatment.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of nausea and repeated vomiting for the past 30 minutes. Two hours ago, he was at a summer barbecue gathering where he ate spicy, freshly grilled chicken that was fully cooked through with some reheated leftover lime basil rice. He has not had diarrhea. Physical examination shows a mildly tender abdomen with no rigidity or rebound tenderness. The next morning, his symptoms have resolved. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Person-to-person transmission of Staphylococcus aureus enterotoxin
Luminal production of heat-stable Escherichia coli toxin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Transmission of Staphylococcus aureus enterotoxins can lead to a rapid onset of nausea and vomiting, which is seen here. However, the S. aureus enterotoxin is transmitted via the ingestion of contaminated food, not from person to person. Furthermore, S. aureus food poisoning is typically caused by the inadequate refrigeration of foods such as mayonnaise, potato salad, and custard rather than reheated rice or freshly cooked meat, which this patient has eaten.

B) INCORRECT:

Listeria monocytogenes causes a foodborne illness that can manifest with nausea and vomiting, which are seen here. Individuals with L. monocytogenes gastroenteritis typically become symptomatic 6 hours to 10 days after ingesting contaminated food and usually report diarrhea. This patient, however, only presents with vomiting 90 minutes after eating contaminated food. Moreover, L. monocytogenes is typically transmitted via unpasteurized dairy products or ready-to-eat deli meats, not reheated rice or freshly cooked meat.

C) INCORRECT:

Salmonella enteritidis infection is a foodborne illness that can manifest with nausea and vomiting, which are seen here. Symptoms usually develop 3–7 days after the ingestion of undercooked poultry or eggs. This patient, however, developed symptoms 90 minutes after eating reheated rice and properly cooked poultry. Furthermore, patients with this infection typically also present with diarrhea and systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, chills, myalgias), none of which are seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

A heat-stable enterotoxin is produced in the intestinal lumen by enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC), which causes a foodborne illness that can manifest with nausea and vomiting. However, ETEC also causes watery diarrhea and symptoms typically develop 1–3 days after the ingestion of contaminated food. This patient has not reported diarrhea, and he developed symptoms within 90 minutes of eating contaminated food.

E) INCORRECT:

Clostridium perfringens food poisoning is a foodborne illness that primarily manifests with diarrhea 7–30 hours after contaminated food is ingested. This patient, however, presents only with vomiting 90 minutes after eating contaminated food. Moreover, C. perfringens spores are commonly found in undercooked or poorly refrigerated food; this patient consumed properly cooked meat and reheated rice.

F) CORRECT:

Improperly refrigerated and reheated starch-containing food (e.g., rice) is a common source of emetic Bacillus cereus food poisoning. B. cereus can form spores, which are heat-resistant and survive the cooking process. If the food is cooled too slowly or improperly refrigerated after cooking, these spores can germinate and produce cereulide, a heat-resistant emetic toxin that causes nausea and vomiting, and/or a heat-labile diarrheal toxin that causes diarrhea. Food poisoning caused by the ingestion of preformed enterotoxins (e.g., from B. cereus and S. aureus) leads to the rapid onset of symptoms within minutes to hours, as seen here.

In comparison, food poisoning caused by bacteria that produce enterotoxins inside the intestines (e.g., enterotoxigenic E. coli, V. cholerae) has a delayed onset (hours to days after ingestion) and typically manifests with watery diarrhea. Foodborne illnesses that manifest with bloody diarrhea usually indicate invasion of the intestinal mucosa by the pathogen (e.g., Campylobacter, Shigella, nontyphoidal Salmonella).
questions.hint: This patient has food poisoning caused by a spore-forming gram-positive rod.
